title: 106_hr752
content: The "Airline Passenger Fairness Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings section of the Act highlights key points related to airline passenger rights. The Congress finds that the number of airline passengers on US carriers is expected to grow significantly, the number of certified large air carriers has decreased, many communities have lost scheduled air service, and there have been significant fare increases in certain city pairs. The Fares Consumer Report for the 3rd Quarter of 1997 identified 75 major city pairs with fare increases of 30% or more, leading to a decrease of 863,500 passengers. A 1998 Department of Transportation study revealed that large US air carriers charge double at hub airports without low fare competition compared to those with low fare competitors. Complaints about airline travel to the Department of Transportation rose by over 25% from the previous year, with complaints against large US air carriers increasing from 6,394 in 1997 to 7,994 in 1998. The 1997 National Civil Aviation Review Commission reported worsening flight delays. The 1997 National Civil Aviation Review Commission reported an increase in complaints against large US air carriers from 6,394 in 1997 to 7,994 in 1998. The report also highlighted a forecast of a 52% increase in passenger enplanements between 1996 and 2006. Additionally, a 1998 Department of Transportation study found that large US air carriers charge significantly more for passengers traveling to or from small communities compared to those traveling between large communities. The Congress has directed the Secretary of Transportation to prohibit unfair and deceptive practices in the airline industry, where large US air carriers charge about 60 percent more for passengers traveling to or from small communities compared to those traveling between large communities. SEC. 3. FAIR PRACTICES FOR AIRLINE PASSENGERS. Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code is amended to include specific practices for certificated air carriers, such as informing passengers about oversold flights, allowing the use of portions of a ticket, timely delivery of checked baggage, and providing full access to all fares. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code includes specific practices for certificated air carriers, such as informing passengers about oversold flights, timely delivery of checked baggage within 24 hours, providing full access to all fares, giving notice of flight delays, accurately informing passengers of reasons for delays, cancellations, or diversions, refunding unused tickets within 48 hours of purchase, and disclosing relevant consumer information. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code requires certificated air carriers to inform passengers accurately of delays, refund unused tickets within 48 hours, and disclose information on frequent flyer programs. The Secretary must report violations in the Air Travel Consumer Report. Confirmed reserved space is defined as a specific date, flight, and class requested by a passenger. The Department of Transportation's monthly Air Travel Consumer Report includes violations by certificated air carriers regarding confirmed reserved space, defined as a specific date, flight, and class requested by a passenger.
